Hi, I‚Äôm Tanay Kasyap-an incoming PhD student in Economics at London Business School.
My research interests are industrial organization, contract theory, and labor economics (with a focus on time use).
Previously, I was a pre-doctoral research fellow at Yale‚Äôs Tobin Center and Economic Growth Center, working with Samuel Kortum and Nicholas Ryan on international trade and dynamic industrial organization with an emphasis on energy markets.
During my pre-doc I analyzed optimal unilateral carbon policy and structural change under climate shocks to agriculture (with Samuel Kortum), and a dynamic entry game for energy firms connecting to the California ISO (CAISO) (with Nicholas Ryan).

title: Research
text:
with Joseph Basford and Daniele Condorelli
Last updated: June 07, 2025

  Abstract
  
    We study a setting in which a privately informed supplier must secure a publicly observed license from a monopolist before selling to a private-value buyer. Licensing fees, tied to subsequent sale terms, optimally take the form of royalties which impose penalties at low prices and which may be negative at high prices to enforce price-maintenance and screen the buyer, yielding allocations equivalent to second-degree price discrimination. Licensing‚Äôs welfare impact is ambiguous ‚Äî it can reduce buyer-driven deadweight loss but introduce supplier inefficiencies. Applied to exclusive-dealing, our model shows such contracts can enhance aggregate welfare, contrary to Aghion & Bolton (1987).

with Peter Hammond
Last updated: June 2025

  Abstract
  
    Following Mertens & Zamir (1985) and Brandenburger & Dekel (1993), universal type spaces have been constructed for each player in a general n-player game of incomplete information, where types encode hierarchies of beliefs. We introduce an analogous construction for games with a continuum of players indexed by the Lebesgue unit interval. For each player, belief types correspond to joint probability measures over triples consisting of (i) the player‚Äôs label, (ii) a non-belief type given by a cardinal equivalence class of payoff functions, and (iii) a recursively constructed hierarchy of belief types. The marginal over player labels must equal Lebesgue measure.

title: Research
text:
Publications

Hierarchies of Beliefs for Many Player Games

Warwick-Monash Economics Student Papers, 2024.


  
    Abstract
    
      Mertens and Zamir (1985) first provided the universal type space construction for finite
player games of incomplete information with a compact state space. Brandenburger and
Dekel (1993) complemented it for a Polish state space. This paper extends the construction
of Brandenburger and Dekel (1993) to games with infinitely many players for Harsanyi‚Äôs
notion of a type. The extension is formulated by randomly drawing a countably infinite
set of actual players from a continuum of potential players, represented by their labels in
[0,1]. The random distribution of the countably infinite set of actual players almost surely
converges to Lebesgue due to the Glivenko‚ÄìCantelli theorem. A coherent type is shown
to induce beliefs over other player‚Äôs types and common knowledge of coherency closes the
model of beliefs. Implications of dropping the Polish space assumption are discussed and
an informal extension to measurable spaces is provided for future work. The formalisation
provided here allows Harsanyi‚Äôs notion of Type.

Estimating How Much Children Work: Questionnaires vs Time Use Diaries

with Juana Lamote de Grignon P√©rez, Federico Blanco Allais, Wenbin Wang, Matthew Henglong Luo, Jialu Tang


Journal of Development Economics (conditionally accepted, 2025).


  
    Abstract
    
      Current estimates of child labour often rely on questions such as, ‚ÄúHow many hours did you work last week?‚Äù While biases in adult self-reports are well-documented in high-income countries, there is limited evidence on the accuracy of children's responses in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Using data from nine LMICs, including China and India, this paper shows that time diaries report more than twice as many work hours as standard questionnaires. This discrepancy suggests that current estimates may significantly understate child labour. Moreover, certain forms of work‚Äîsuch as collecting water or firewood‚Äîappear to contribute to these measurement gaps.
